longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Compensation of employees paid by financial corporations sector

shortname: Compensation of employees paid by general government
simpledes: Compensation of employees paid by general government is the total value of income accruing to employees as remuneration for their work paid by general government sector (central government, state government, local government, and social security funds).The government sector - in the national accounts - includes are national, regional local governement, social security administrations, and more generally all entities relying primarily upon public financing (taxes, contributions, and other compulsory payments).

shortname: Compensation of employees paid by non financial corporations

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

shortname: Corporate equity, fund shares & offshore wealth
simpledes: Corporate equity, fund shares & offshore wealth are company stocks, fund shares and wealth outside of one's residence country owned by the corporate sector (companies). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
technicaldes: [Corporate equity, fund shares & offshore wealth]=[Corporate equities]+[Corporate offshore wealth]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310. Series updated by the same authors.;

simpledes: Corporate financial assets are intangible assets whose value is derived from a contractual claim (bank deposits, bonds, and stocks) owned by the corporate sector (companies). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Net corporate wealth is the total value of assets (cash, housing, bonds, equities, etc.) owned by the corporate sector (companies), minus its debts. The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
technicaldes: [Residual corporate wealth]=[Book value of corporations]-[Market value of corporations (equity liability)]

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Factor national income is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows of personal sector accruing directly or indirectly to the individual owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, and before taking into account the operation of pension system.

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Fiscal capital income [total fiscal income ranking]
simpledes: Fiscal capital income  is income received by virtue of owning capital.  Reported on income tax returns before any specific deduction.
technicaldes: [Fiscal capital income [total fiscal income ranking]]=[Capital component of mixed income]+[Rents]+[Interest]+[Dividends]+[Capital gains]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Dividends are payments from corporations to shareholders, usually as a distribution of profits.  Reported on income tax returns before any specific deduction.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income [total fiscal income ranking]]+[Fiscal capital income [total fiscal income ranking]]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The population looked at is comprised of female individuals only.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Piketty, Thomas and Saez, Emmanuel (2007). Income and Wage Inequality in the United States 1913-2002; in Atkinson, A. B. and Piketty, T. (editors) Top Incomes over the Twentieth Century. A Contrast Between Continental European and English-Speaking Countries, Oxford University Press, chapter 5. Series updated by the same authors.;
method: Tax units are families (see source for details). Includes capital gains.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1960–1969: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2021 from: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 1960–2022: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1960–1969: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Government agricultural land is agricultural land owned by the general government sector (central government, state government, local government, and social security funds). Agricultural land is defined as land devoted to agriculture. The government sector - in the national accounts - includes are national, regional local governement, social security administrations, and more generally all entities relying primarily upon public financing (taxes, contributions, and other compulsory payments).
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Government other domestic capital is non-financial assets owned by the general government sector (central government, state government, local government, and social security funds) except housing assets and agricultural land (machinery, equipment, etc.). The government sector - in the national accounts - includes are national, regional local governement, social security administrations, and more generally all entities relying primarily upon public financing (taxes, contributions, and other compulsory payments).

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.  The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The population looked at is comprised of female individuals only.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/the-rise-of-income-and-wealth-inequality-in-america-evidence-from-distributional-macroeconomic-accounts-world-inequality-lab-wp-2020-20/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Saez, E., Zucman, G. (2020), The Rise of Income and Wealth Inequality in America: Evidence from Distributional Macroeconomic Accounts[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

shortname: Personal equity, fund shares & offshore wealth
simpledes: Personal equity, fund shares & offshore wealth are company stocks, fund shares and wealth outside of one's residence country owned by the personal sector (households).. The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Personal equity, fund shares & offshore wealth]=[Personal equities]+[Personal offshore wealth]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310. Series updated by the same authors.;
method: Includes money market fund shares + equities owned through funds.

shortname: Personal equity, fund shares & offshore wealth

shortname: Personal financial assets excluding currency & deposits
simpledes: Personal financial assets excluding cash are financial assets except cash and bank deposits owned by the personal sector (households).. The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Personal financial assets excluding currency & deposits]=[Personal financial assets]-[Personal currency, bonds & deposits]

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Personal financial assets excluding currency & deposits
simpledes: Personal financial assets excluding cash are financial assets except cash and bank deposits owned by the personal sector (households).. The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Personal financial assets excluding currency & deposits]=[Personal financial assets]-[Personal currency, bonds & deposits]

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Personal financial assets include bank deposits, bonds, stocks and other financial claims held by households. simpledes: Other domestic personal capital includes all non-financial assets held by households and foundations, except housing assets and agricultural land: machinery, equipment, patents, etc.  The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Non-profit equity, fund shares & offshore wealth
simpledes: Non-profit equity, fund shares & offshore wealth are company stocks, fund shares and wealth outside of one's residence country held by non-profit institutions . The non-profit sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all non-profit institutions serving households (NPISH), such as foundations, religious organizations, etc.
technicaldes: [Non-profit equity, fund shares & offshore wealth]=[Non-profit equities]+[Non-profit offshore wealth]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310. Series updated by the same authors.;

simpledes: Non-profit housing assets are dwellings (including land underlying dwellings) held by non-profit institutions. The non-profit sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all non-profit institutions serving households (NPISH), such as foundations, religious organizations, etc.
technicaldes: [Non-profit housing assets]=[Non-profit dwellings]+[Non-profit land underlying dwellings]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Non-profit non-financial assets include housing, land and all other domestic material and immaterial assets (machinery, equipment, patents, etc.) held directly by non-profit institutions, as opposed to non-financial assets owned indirectly through financial assets (equities, bonds, etc. in corporations holding non-financial assets).  The non-profit sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all non-profit institutions serving households (NPISH), such as foundations, religious organizations, etc.
technicaldes: [Non-profit non-financial assets]=[Non-profit housing assets]+[Non-profit business and other non-financial assets]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: PPP conversion factor, LCU per EUR
simpledes: PPP conversion factor of current local currency to current PPP EUR.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=PPP2011[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: We extrapolate the PPP from the latest ICP (2017) using the evolution of the price index relative to the reference country.

We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations. However it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). So we use it as our reference concept (with tax havens correction). To be improved.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Net operating surplus of non-financial corporations
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. simpledes: National agricultural land is agricultural land owned by the national economy. Agricultural land is defined as land devoted to agriculture measured at their market value. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

simpledes: Book-value national wealth is the sum of value of assets according to the books (balance sheets) on which they are carried. It is the difference between net national wealth and national net corporate wealth. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Book-value national wealth]=[Market-value national wealth ]+[Residual corporate wealth]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: National residual corporate wealth is the total value of debts and legal obligations of the corporate sector (companies), minus the total value of its assets. The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Net foreign assets are the total value of the assets that a country owns abroad, minus the total value of the domestic assets owned by foreigners. technicaldes: [Net foreign assets]=[Gross foreign assets]-[Gross foreign liabilities]

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Property income paid from the rest of the world
simpledes: Property income paid abroad is the total value of payments made by the national economy accruing to property owners as remuneration for using their property.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The population looked at is comprised of female individuals only.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals between ages 20 and 39.

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014). Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2016–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1960–2015: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014). Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Net private wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities of corporations, etc.) held by private owners (households and foundations), minus their debts.  The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Net private wealth]=[Private non-financial assets]+[Private financial assets]-[Private debt]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310. Series updated by the same authors.;

shortname: Private equity, fund shares & offshore wealth
simpledes: Private equity, fund shares & offshore wealth are company stocks, fund shares and wealth outside of one's residence country held by private owners (households and foundations). The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Private equity, fund shares & offshore wealth]=[Private equities]+[Private offshore wealth]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310. Series updated by the same authors.;

In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Private non-financial assets]=[Private housing assets]+[Private business assets]

technicaldes: [Private pension funds & life insurance]=[Personal pension funds & life insurance]+[Non-profit pension funds & life insurance]

The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Net secondary income/Net saving of corporations
technicaldes: [Net secondary income/Net saving of corporations]=[Net primary income of corporations]-[Corporate tax]+[Social contributions to private employer social insurance]-[Social benefits from private employer social insurance]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Post-tax national income is the sum of primary incomes over all sectors (private and public), minus taxes.
technicaldes: [Post-tax national income]=[Post-tax disposable income]+[Public spending]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: After 1962, [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/t-piketty-e-saez-g-zucman-data-appendix-to-distributional-national-accounts-methods-and-estimates-for-the-united-states-2016/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Saez, Emmanuel and Zucman, Gabriel (2016). Distributional National Accounts: Methods and Estimates for the United States; [/URL_TEXT][/URL] Before 1962, [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/examining-the-great-leveling-new-evidence-on-midcentury-american-inequality/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Fisher-Post, Matthew (2020). Examining the Great Leveling: New Evidence on Midcentury American Inequality; [/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/WorldInequalityLab_WP2020_20_US-IncomeWealthInequality.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Saez, Emmanuel and Zucman, Gabriel (2020). The Rise of Income and Wealth Inequality in America: Evidence from Distributional Macroeconomic Accounts; [/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]http://gabriel-zucman.eu/files/PSZUpdates.pdf[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Zucman, Gabriel (2020). Technical Note “US Distributional National Accounts: Updates” [/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/real-time-inequality-world-inequality-lab-working-paper-2022-14/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Blanchet, Thomas, Saez, Emmanuel and Zucman, Gabriel (2022). “Real-Time Inequality" [/URL_TEXT][/URL]

simpledes: Factor national income is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows of personal sector accruing directly or indirectly to the individual owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, and before taking into account the operation of pension system.
technicaldes: Pre-tax factor income=Factor labor income [total pre-tax factor income ranking]+Factor capital income [total pre-tax factor income ranking]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income [total fiscal income ranking]]+[Fiscal capital income [total fiscal income ranking]]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Piketty, Thomas and Saez, Emmanuel (2007). Income and Wage Inequality in the United States 1913-2002; in Atkinson, A. B. and Piketty, T. (editors) Top Incomes over the Twentieth Century. A Contrast Between Continental European and English-Speaking Countries, Oxford University Press, chapter 5. Series updated by the same authors.;
method: Tax units are families (see source for details). Includes capital gains.

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.  The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/the-rise-of-income-and-wealth-inequality-in-america-evidence-from-distributional-macroeconomic-accounts-world-inequality-lab-wp-2020-20/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Saez, E., Zucman, G. (2020), The Rise of Income and Wealth Inequality in America: Evidence from Distributional Macroeconomic Accounts[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. method: Modeled estimates based on the systematic combination of survey and tax data, national accounts and Environment Input-Output tables. Estimates represent emissions associated with individual investments (i.e. these are emissions associated with “capital formation“, attributed to individual who own firms). This indicator does not include emissions associated with individual consumption and government collective expenditures. While these estimates provide WID.world's best efforts to measure emissions inequality across the world, it should be noted that estimates quality is “low to very low“ given poor data quality and availability on pollution in most countries. It should also be noted that there are different ways to measure carbon footprints, which can lead to different takes on the issue (inequality in emissions is lower when looking at consumption-related emissions only and increases when factoring in investment-related emissions). See sources for more details.

simpledes: Post-tax national income is the sum of primary incomes over all sectors (private and public), minus taxes.
technicaldes: [Post-tax national income]=[Post-tax disposable income]+[Public spending]
longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Factor national income is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows of personal sector accruing directly or indirectly to the individual owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, and before taking into account the operation of pension system.
technicaldes: Pre-tax factor income=Factor labor income [total pre-tax factor income ranking]+Factor capital income [total pre-tax factor income ranking]
longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.  The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

(2020), The Rise of Income and Wealth Inequality in America: Evidence from Distributional Macroeconomic Accounts[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.

simpledes: Tobin's Q is the ratio between the market value of corporations (stock market capitalisation) and the book value of corporations (assets minus debt). The corporate sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all financial and non-financial corporations with an economic activity in a given country, whatever their legal status (with the exceptions of unincorporated enterprises included in the personal sector).

method: Modeled estimates based on the systematic combination of survey and tax data, national accounts and Environment Input-Output tables. Estimates represent emissions associated with individual investments (i.e. these are emissions associated with “capital formation“, attributed to individual who own firms). This indicator does not include emissions associated with individual consumption and government collective expenditures. While these estimates provide WID.world's best efforts to measure emissions inequality across the world, it should be noted that estimates quality is “low to very low“ given poor data quality and availability on pollution in most countries. It should also be noted that there are different ways to measure carbon footprints, which can lead to different takes on the issue (inequality in emissions is lower when looking at consumption-related emissions only and increases when factoring in investment-related emissions). See sources for more details.

method: Total carbon footprint is equal to CO2 footprint + footprint of other greenhouse gases.1980-1984: EORA detailed input output tables; 1985-1990 Eora detailed input output tables adjusted to smooth differences due to methodological differences before and after 1990  1990-2015: CO2 footprint data from GCP converted into GHG using GHG/CO2 ratios from EORA footprint estimations; 2016-2019: Same methodology with GHG/CO2 ratio assumed constant and equal to the 2015 ratio from EORA footprint estimations; 2020: Regional extrapolation using coefficients from IEA. method: Modeled estimates based on the systematic combination of survey and tax data, national accounts and Environment Input-Output tables. Estimates include emissions embedded in imports and exports of goods and services. Estimates represent emissions associated with individual consumption and with government collective expenditures. This indicator does not include emissions associated with individual investments. While these estimates provide WID.world's best efforts to measure emissions inequality across the world, it should be noted that estimates quality is “low to very low“ given poor data quality and availability on pollution in most countries. It should also be noted that there are different ways to measure carbon footprints, which can lead to different takes on the issue (inequality in emissions is lower when looking at consumption-related emissions only and increases when factoring in investment-related emissions). See sources for more details.
