simpledes: Interest payments are payments that are made by borrowers to lenders above repayments of the principal sum.
technicaldes: Interest payments=Mortgage interest paid+Non-mortgage interest paid
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Interest income is payments that lenders receive above repayments of the principal sum.
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
simpledes: Pre-tax capital income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the individual owners of capital as a production factor, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]=Housing asset income+Equity asset income+Interest income+Pensions and social insurance income (capital share)-Interest payments
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Labor component of net mixed income
simpledes: Labor component of net mixed income  is net mixed income that is derived from providing labour as a factor of production. Net mixed income is defined as the surplus or deficit accruing from production by unincorporated enterprises owned by households (sometimes termed as "business income").  Reported on income tax returns before any specific deduction.
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]
simpledes: Pre-tax labor income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the individual owners of labor as a production factor, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]=Compensation of employees +Labor component of net mixed income +Pensions and social insurance income (labor share)
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Capital component of mixed income is net mixed income that is derived from providing capital as a factor of production. Net mixed income is defined as the surplus or deficit accruing from production by unincorporated enterprises owned by households (sometimes termed as "business income").  Reported on income tax returns before any specific deduction. Reported on income tax returns before any specific deduction.
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

shortname: Pensions and social insurance income (labor share)
simpledes: Pensions and social insurance income (labor share) are the labour share of payments made by pension funds and social insurance system. The labour share of payments is the share received by providing labour as a factor of production.
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Post-tax national income is the sum of primary incomes over all sectors (private and public), minus taxes.
technicaldes: [Post-tax national income]=[Post-tax disposable income]+[Public spending]
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'
longpop: The population looked at is comprised of female individuals only.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income [total fiscal income ranking]]+[Fiscal capital income [total fiscal income ranking]]
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'
longpop: The population looked at is comprised of female individuals only.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Piketty, Thomas and Saez, Emmanuel (2007). Income and Wage Inequality in the United States 1913-2002; in Atkinson, A. B. and Piketty, T. (editors) Top Incomes over the Twentieth Century. A Contrast Between Continental European and English-Speaking Countries, Oxford University Press, chapter 5. Series updated by the same authors.;

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts.  The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/the-rise-of-income-and-wealth-inequality-in-america-evidence-from-distributional-macroeconomic-accounts-world-inequality-lab-wp-2020-20/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Saez, E., Zucman, G. (2020), The Rise of Income and Wealth Inequality in America: Evidence from Distributional Macroeconomic Accounts[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Percentile (i.e. threshold ) value at pX, whether the percentile is of the form 'pX' or of the form 'pXpY'

longtype: Proportion of net national income
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2021 from: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 1960–2022: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1960–2022: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations. However it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). So we use it as our reference concept (with tax havens correction). To be improved.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]

simpledes: National residual corporate wealth is the total value of debts and legal obligations of the corporate sector (companies), minus the total value of its assets. technicaldes: [Net foreign capital income]=[Net foreign direct investment income]+[Net portfolio income]
longtype: Proportion of net national income
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1960–1969: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Net private wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities of corporations, etc.) held by private owners (households and foundations), minus their debts.  The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Net private wealth]=[Private non-financial assets]+[Private financial assets]-[Private debt]
longtype: Proportion of net national income
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310. Series updated by the same authors.;

simpledes: Private non-financial assets include housing, land and all other domestic material and immaterial assets (machinery, equipment, patents, etc.) held directly by private owners (households and foundations), as opposed to non-financial assets owned indirectly through financial assets (equities, bonds, etc. in corporations holding non-financial assets).  The private sector - in the national accounts sense - includes the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (foundations, religious organizations, etc.). In certain countries, availables sources do not allow to decompose the wealth owned by each of these two sub-sectors, and we only provide total net private wealth.
technicaldes: [Private non-financial assets]=[Private housing assets]+[Private business assets]

source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1960–1969: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Net foreign income is the difference between the total value of a country's citizens and companies earned abroad, and the total value of foreign citizens and overseas companies earned in that country.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign income]=[Property income received from the rest of the world]-[Property income paid from the rest of the world]+[Compensation of employees received from the rest of the world]-[Compensation of employees paid from the rest of the world]

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations. However it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). So we use it as our reference concept (with tax havens correction). To be improved.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]

simpledes: Gross foreign assets are the total value of the assets that country owns abroad. simpledes: Net foreign assets are the total value of the assets that a country owns abroad, minus the total value of the domestic assets owned by foreigners. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign assets]=[Gross foreign assets]-[Gross foreign liabilities]

simpledes: Property income paid abroad is the total value of payments made by the national economy accruing to property owners as remuneration for using their property.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Property income paid to the rest of the world]=[Foreign direct investment income paid to the rest of the world]+[Portfolio and other income paid to the rest of the world]
longtype: Proportion of gross domestic product
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][/URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1970–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1960–1969: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2016–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]https://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=SNA_TABLE14A[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1960–2015: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/revised-extended-national-wealth-series-australia-canada-france-germany-italy-japan-uk-usa-wid-world-technical-note-2017-23/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty, Thomas; Zucman, Gabriel (2014). Capital is back: Wealth-Income ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010. Series updated by Luis Bauluz.[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.
